title: refactor(www): Make the dot-org sidebar into a function component
body:
## Description

Turn www/src/components/sidebar/sidebar.js into a function component.

## Motivation

The sidebar performance is really slow: #21533. Changing it to a function component with hooks would let us reason about the state updates better, and would prevent gotchas that are present in class components.

Sidebar performance is also an issue for localization: #20587. We're going to have to add more functionality in order to make the sidebar localizable and it's easier to do that with an updated codebase.

title: [docs] Use soft-line wraps for all markdown pages.
body:
## Description

There are a couple of (mostly older) markdown pages that still use hard line wraps for paragraphs. This poses a problem for localization, since the lines will be split up and it will be a hassle to track.

We should convert these to use soft line wraps like most of the gatsby docs for easier readibily, maintainability, and translation.

## Example

From how-shadowing-works.md:

```md
Shadowing is a powerful feature that allows theme users to override components,
objects, and anything else in a theme's `src` directory.
```

But it should be:

```md
Shadowing is a powerful feature that allows theme users to override components, objects, and anything else in a theme's `src` directory.
```

title: Include details on blog post fields on gatsby-theme-blog
body:
#  Summary

When installing and using the gatsby-theme-blog, details past initial installation and configuration are absent. The user has to guess the fields or look through source code to find what blog post fields are available or even required for the theme to work.

Appending information on the blog post fields to the existing readme files of gatsby-theme-blog-core and gatsby-theme-blog should help solve this issue.

### Motivation

We should document this to ensure a smooth theme installation and usage and uphold a standard of giving users all the important information.

### Draft the doc

#### Blog Post Fields

The following are the defined blog post fields based on the node interface in the schema

| Field    | Type     |
| -------- | -------- |
| id       | String   |
| title    | String   |
| body     | String   |
| slug     | String   |
| date     | Date     |
| tags     | String[] |
| keywords | String[] |
| excerpt  | String   |

Make website components used in MDX files globally available through gatsby-plugin-theme-ui.

The only way to import components in MDX is to use relative paths, which breaks when pulling in content from translation repos.

* GuideList
* EggheadEmbed

## Related Issues

title: [gatsby-plugin-sharp] Incorrect require path to cpu detection module.
body:
## Description
Within process-file.js, there's a `require` statement that's pointing to maybe an old path to where cpu-core-count.js should be. It should be changed to `gatsby/dist/utils/worker/cpu-core-count`. By default, sharp uses the number of CPUs it detects, but this logic could be different than what Gatsby defines as the number of CPUs in cpu-core-count.js.

### Steps to reproduce
This doesn't really have a reproducible step, as it's just code that isn't being used due to a bad path with no caught error logged.

### Expected result
Either the error that happens due to the path being bad is caught and reported to screen, or the path is updated and cpu-core-count.js is used, allowing `sharp.concurrency` to be set to the value of cpuCoreCount from the cpu-core-count.js file.
`sharp.concurrency` should then return the value from the cpu-core-count.js file once it's been set the first time.

### Actual result
`sharp.concurrency` returns the number of CPUs it detected after being failing to be set by cpu-core-count.js.

### Environment

title: [v1] stylus plugin use and import cannot work together

## Description

I'm using the following config:

```js

      resolve: 'gatsby-plugin-stylus',
      options: {

        import: [

When setting `dashes` to `oldSchool` or `inverted` three dashes will always render an HR to the DOM. _I don't see how this could ever work because three dashes are converted to a Horizontal Rule in standard Markdown and I'm guessing this will always take priority._

### Steps to reproduce

```
{
  resolve: `gatsby-remark-smartypants`,
  options: {
    dashes: `oldschool`, // Two dashes for an en-dash, three for an em-dash

}
```

3. Type three dashes in a markdown document:

```

According to the linked docs an em-dash should be rendered to the DOM.

An HR is rendered to the DOM

title: plugin: Post-build HTML Validation
body:
## Summary

How about a plugin to run post-build that runs each page that has been built through an HTML validator and reports on any validation errors? Although it's harder to make these kind of errors nowadays thanks to the fact so much of the html is generated and editors are much better at flagging these errors early on, I think this might still be useful.

### Motivation

There are two very good reasons to ensure HTML is valid:

1. There are a wealth of subtle CSS errors that can be causes by invalid HTML given the variety in how browsers handle invalid markup.
2. HTML validity is a signal used by Google in ranking a site.
author: Undistraction

title: Warn if context values passed to createPage are different types than others or empty
body:
Someone creating pages could run into a mysterious GraphQL error if any of the pages context has missing information:

```
Errors:
GraphQLError: Variable "$slug" of required type "String!" was not provided.
```

This is hard for someone new to Gatsby to debug. We should check against this and warn.

title: Add peerDependencies to every plugin
body: Going forward, we'll be doing every so often major releases for Gatsby but individual plugins might not need upgraded as the APIs they depend on won't have changed. We should prepare for that now by adding a `peerDependencies` for Gatsby to every plugin. Then when there is a breaking change that affects the plugin or there's a new major release of Gatsby, we update the peerDependencies for the plugin.

title: Output warning the graphql inference process drops fields due to type mis-matches
body:
Users are surprised sometimes due to fields in their data being dropped due to mis-matched types. Instead of silently dropping data, we should output a warning about the data source (file(s), external API, etc) and any transformers involved and examples of the mis-matched data.

#2404 is an example of an issue coming from the lack of this warning and there's been more in the past.

/cc @danoc @jquense
